title: 109_hr5612
content: The Act titled "Chattahoochee National Forest Act of 2006" establishes the Mountaintown National Scenic Area within the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area is established in the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia, covering approximately 13,382 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide a final map and boundary description to Congress, with the same legal effect as if included in the Act. The Secretary may correct errors in the map and boundary description for the Mountaintown National Scenic Area. The map and description must be available for public inspection. In case of any discrepancy, the description required by this subsection will take precedence. The area will be managed for the purpose of ensuring appropriate protection. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area is managed to protect and preserve scenic quality, water quality, natural characteristics, and water resources. It also aims to manage vegetation for wildlife habitat, develop old-growth forest characteristics, and provide various recreation opportunities. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area is managed to protect scenic quality, water resources, and wildlife habitat. A management plan must be developed within three years, prioritizing management purposes over general laws and regulations. After the enactment of this Act, no new roads can be built in the scenic area, except for access to private lands. Timber harvest is prohibited in the scenic area, except for necessary vegetation management. The scenic area prohibits timber harvest, except for necessary vegetation management. Motorized travel is not allowed, except for administrative use authorized by the Secretary. Firewood can be harvested for personal use under specified conditions. The scenic area prohibits timber harvest, except for necessary vegetation management. Motorized travel is not allowed, except for administrative use authorized by the Secretary. Firewood can be harvested for personal use under specified conditions. In furtherance of management purposes, wildfires will be suppressed, insect and disease outbreaks controlled, and water quality maintained or enhanced in the scenic area. Mining Withdrawal: All federally owned lands in the scenic area are withdrawn from mining laws and leasing claims to protect water quality and preserve the environment. SEC. 3. DESIGNATION OF ADDITIONAL NATIONAL FOREST SYSTEM LAND AS WILDERNESS IN GEORGIA. Designation of approximately 8,448 acres in Georgia as wilderness under the Wilderness Act, adding three areas to the Southern Nantahala Wilderness. Designation of new wilderness areas in Georgia includes additions to existing wilderness areas such as Blood Mountain, Brasstown, Ellicott Rock, Cohutta, and Raven Cliffs. The additions range in size from 165 to 1085 acres. One addition to Raven Cliffs Wilderness: Helton Creek, 2,451 acres. One addition to Tray Mountain Wilderness: Tripp Branch, 638 acres. Secretary to submit final maps and descriptions of designated wilderness lands to Congress. The Secretary shall administer designated wilderness lands in accordance with the Wilderness Act and make maps and boundary descriptions available for public inspection. The Wilderness Act references the enactment date of this Act. Georgia retains jurisdiction over fish and wildlife in Chattahoochee National Forest. Federal land designated as wilderness is withdrawn from public entry, appropriation, or disposal.
